defaults: The application is CRUD-only unless the task description explicitly requires additional workflows.
The application is non-interactive (no prompts, no stdin) unless explicitly required.
Each invocation performs exactly one operation described by a single JSON command provided via the command line.
prohibitions: Do not introduce non-CRUD workflows (e.g., checkout/return flows) unless explicitly required by the task description.
Do not describe flags/options/subcommands unless explicitly required by the task description.

app_story: Describe only what the application does at a user/outcome level.
Name only the minimal user-facing entities involved (if any).
State that data persists locally as JSON between runs when persistence is required.
Do NOT mention any internal architecture, layers, or implementation details.
entry_point: Must include the program name and how to run it (e.g., python main.py).
Must describe the basic input behavior in one sentence and the basic output behavior in one sentence.
Must specify that results are printed to stdout as a single JSON object per invocation.
Must specify deterministic exit codes: 0 for success, 2 for user/validation/not-found/conflict errors, 1 for internal errors.
Do NOT describe complex CLI features (flags, options, subcommands), stdin input, interactive prompts, or REPL behavior unless explicitly required by the task description.

hard_prohibitions: No execution-model phrasing such as 'entry point', 'startup', 'invokes', 'wires', 'initializes', 'calls', or similar lifecycle language.
No markdown fences or code blocks.
No class names, module names, file paths, or method/function signatures.
No mention of internal components, layers, frameworks, or design patterns.
No advanced features (authentication, synchronization, plugins, UI, multi-user) unless explicitly required by the task description.
No CLI argument parsing complexity (flags, options, subcommands) unless explicitly required by the task description.
No cross-entity workflows beyond CRUD unless explicitly required by the task description.
style_constraints: Avoid marketing language and subjective claims.
Avoid examples beyond basic run usage.
Avoid enumerating internal steps or describing internal control flow.
All sections must be phrased in terms of observable behavior and guarantees, not how the program is started or executed internally.
domain_policy_rules: If the task requires CRUD, state that the application supports create, list, get, update, and delete operations at a high level, without describing command syntax.
If the task requires identifier handling, state the ID policy at a user-facing level only (e.g., records are created with explicit ids; ids must be unique).
If persistence is required, state that each operation is atomic: on failure, no partial changes are persisted.
If the task requires multiple entity types, mention only the entity names and their high-level purpose.
If persistence is required, specify that data is stored locally in JSON files under a local data directory, without naming paths or filenames.
example_handling_rules: Any examples provided in context are format examples only.
Do not copy example-specific domain content, entity names, or workflows unless explicitly required by the current task description.
Always generate fresh content tailored to the current task description.
If an example conflicts with the current task description, the task description wins.
If the task description is generic, use neutral naming derived from the task (e.g., records/items/entries).
validation_notes: App Story must be one paragraph and contain no internal implementation references.
Entry Point must be one paragraph and must include run command, stdout behavior, and exit code behavior.
If persistence is mentioned, the story must imply atomic behavior (operations fully succeed or have no effect).
Both sections must remain compatible with a fixed layered architecture, without naming it.
architecture: Must describe only user-observable runtime characteristics (e.g., offline operation, determinism, single execution per run) that can be verified by running the program.
Must NOT describe startup, invocation, wiring, control flow, or internal execution steps.
Must NOT imply the existence of internal layers, lifecycle phases, or architectural components.
